awd_titl_txt: Reaction kinetics and solvation: from computational methods to practical theories
awd_abstract_narration:
Baron Peters of the University of California, Santa Barbara, is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division for to develop simple and accurate theories to study chemical reactions in solution.   Such reactions are central to many natural and industrial processes, including our own biochemistry.   Current simulation approaches that treat the solvent as a polarizable continuum have severe limitations.  Other, more sophisticated simulation approaches are able to predict rates but often do not give any insight into the underlying mechanisms of the reaction.   The ability to predict rates without mechanistic understanding seems like an advantage, but these analyses do not help researchers graduate from large scale computation to simple, accurate, and understandable models.  Simple theoretical models, such as those developed in this project; help scientists engineer processes involving complex reactions.  Moreover, simple models can both predict rates and interpret rate data from experiments.  The proposed work will have potential impact on chemistry, physics, biology, geology, materials science and engineering.  Peters and his research group develop software, documentation, and YouTube tutorials to help others perform these analyses with LAMMPS (Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator; Sandia National Laboratories), CHARMM (Chemistry at HARvard Macromolecular Mechanics), and other widely used software packages.  


The simple but accurate theories that have been developed for gas phase reactions, surface reactions, and electron transfer reactions share one common characteristic: they are built around a single reaction coordinate which accurately summarizes the mechanism.  In contrast, solvent reaction coordinates remain elusive.  Peters and coworkers propose a new strategy for constructing the solvent coordinates using procedures that can be applied across broad families of reactions with similar electrostatic characteristics. The approach combines elements of continuum solvation approaches, variational transition state theory, energy gap coordinates from electron transfer theory, and a new polarization progress coordinate. The relative importance of these coordinates will be determined using transition path sampling and likelihood maximization approaches.  Instead of directly generating rates, this computational analysis guides the construction of simple rate theories that can be used to predict trends across entire reaction families.  These results are used to classify reactions in solution into mechanistic families and to develop practical rules-of-thumb for equilibrium and non-equilibrium solvation effects across the different reaction families.

Title: Reaction Kinetics and Solvation: From Computational Methods to Practical Theories

The main objective was to move beyond computational methods that choose reaction coordinates and compute rates on a case-by-case basis, one system at time.  We focused on the challenging case of reactions in polar solvents and proposed the following strategy: 

  • Categorize reactions into groups with similar mechanisms. 
  • Construct one simple physically interpretable reaction coordinate for each category
  • Use the reaction coordinate to construct models of the free energy barrier in terms of physically meaningful parameters, 
  • Use the free energy models to anticipate trends in rates across each category of reactions.  

Our strategy was motivated by three widely useful theories that were all developed this way: transition state theory, Marcus theory of electron transfer, and classical nucleation theory.

Intellectual merit: We studied reactions in polar solvents according to three categories: (1) reactions that involve ion migration with no charge transfer, (2) reactions where charge transfer and atom migration are coupled, and (3) reactions where charge transfer occurs between stationary donor and acceptor ions. Category (3) was largely solved by Marcus, so we focused on categories (1) and (2).  Basic components of the strategy were outlined and justified in these two publications: 

  • Common Features of Extraordinary Rate Theories, B. Peters, J. Phys. Chem. B. (2015). 
  • Reaction coordinates and mechanistic hypothesis tests, B. Peters, Ann. Rev. Phys. Chem. 67, 669 (2016).  

For category (1) we studied spiral growth of ionic crystals, in which ions attach at kink sites on the crystal surface.   This is the mechanism by which crystals from table salt to acetominophen (tylenol) are grown at low supersaturation.  A theory for spiral growth rates was developed long ago by Burton and others.  Their theory has been widely used to correlate and interpret experimental data, but it cannot make predictions because multiple parameters within the theory had never been computed.  We used our strategy to make the first parameter-free spiral growth rate predictions, and found remarkable agreement between theory and experiment.  Results were published in these four papers. 

  • Rate Expressions for Kink Attachment and Detachment During Crystal Growth. J. Li et al., Cryst. Growth & Des. (2016).  
  • Critical length of a one-dimensional nucleus. Joswiak et al., J. Chem. Phys. (2016).  
  • Desolvation Barriers in Ionic Crystal Growth: Kink Attachment/Detachment for NaCl in Water, Joswiak et al., Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci., (2018).
  • In Silico Crystal Growth Rate Prediction for NaCl from Aqueous Solution, Joswiak et al., Cryst. Growth & Des. (2018). 

For category (2), we identified a solvent coordinate for SN2 reactions.  The new coordinate quantifies solvent induced solute polarization.  Rate calculations and accuracy tests for the new coordinate were reported in

  • Solvent Reaction Coordinate for an SN2 Reaction, Leitold et al., J. Chem. Phys. (2020) 

We also contributed method and theory advances including: a method to recover accurate rates from first passage time calculations with an inaccurate reaction coordinate [Yappert et al, J. Chem. Phys (2019)], an analysis showing that infrequent metadynamics is more susceptible to errors and less efficient than other rare events methods [Khan et al., J. Chem. Phys (2020)], a highly efficient method for computing free energy differences between polymorphs [Kamat et al. J. Phys. Chem. Lett. (2017)], and a method for computing compositions of two solid solutions (alloys) at equilibrium with each other [Anwar et al., J. Chem. Phys. (2020)]. 

Broader Impacts: We pursued several educational objectives as part of this project.  First, Peters organized a summer school on Rare Events Methods and Reaction Rate Theory at the Indian Institute of Science in Bangalore, India (7/2019).  The school included one week of pedagogical lectures  and hands-on exercises by seven instructors: Sarupria, Jonsson, Shukla, Touchette, Peters, Punnathanam, and Taraphder.  40 PhD students attended (in-person) from institutions around the world. 

Second, Peters developed a new graduate kinetics and reaction engineering course at the University of Illinois with expanded emphasis on topics for students working in soft matter, biology, and materials research areas.  In fall 2021 (second offering) the course enrollment grew to 43 with approximately 1/3 of the students coming from PhD programs in Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering, Materials Science, and Nuclear Engineering.  

Third, Peters developed a series of videos on reaction rate theory, rare events, and reaction engineering.  The content includes 12 total hours, spread over 47 edited videos. The material has a cumulative 28K views on YouTube.   

Finally, Peters gave 24 invited lectures to disseminate results from this project.
